title: The Mission of Jesus Christ (The Paschal Mystery)
subject: Theology

document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

3978CEE632634E7985460571ED395DD7.description:
One must never do evil just so that good may come
of it (CCC, no. 1789).

747250C66A9D4D47B429386327F90611.description:
A good end never justifies an evil means (CCC,
no. 1753).

1EC83C5E7D674B2F8CD9956330668678.description:
No. Every moral choice that a person makes has
an effect on the person and society (CCC, nos.
1749-1756).

0B3CD371971C48E5BBD7AE25E4B9C93C.description:
In the end, isn’t it really only the final result that
matters?

4E56D4B0072D49EBB3E579002DFD1AB5.description:
Suffering is necessary to develop our maturity in
Christ and to love our neighbor as Christ loves him
(Col 1:24; CCC, nos. 1808, 1831).

13965BBC6DE64D58BA57CA583BC3C148.description:
Jesus teaches us both in word and by example to
refrain from revenge and to forgive those who hurt
or sin against us (CCC, nos. 2842-2845).

986A7D6DD7034DCC88A5992E47FC5A71.description:
He gives us the example of accepting the Father’s
will even when it involves suffering.

B6F1BC9CCA7F48BA9269FE73A750AB96.description:
Jesus shows us through the whole Paschal Mystery
(suffering, Death, Resurrection, and Ascension)
that giving of ourselves is the path to eternal life
and happiness (CCC, nos. 571-655).

616FE2211CA442C8BAA13EB357142F1D.description:
No. Making sacrifices and putting up with suffering
requires a great deal of courage and strength. Jesus
teaches us, by example, about the value of unselfish
living and the courage and strength that requires.
It takes grace and personal holiness to live as Jesus
Christ has taught us.

9AC7640249EE46F485A57336BC336035.description:
Isn’t making sacrifices and putting up with suffering a
sign of weakness (CCC, nos. 1808, 1831)?

F28392C133AA486C83D7650E63C8831B.description:
Christ strengthens the person to undergo suffering
and thereby become more like Christ himself. Our
suffering, when united with his own, can become a
means of purification and of salvation for us and for
others (CCC, nos. 618, 1505).

F3CC75EC151244639CE8455CFEFBA2B7.description:
Finally, the suffering, Death, Resurrection,
and Ascension of Jesus teaches us to look
beyond the sufferings of this world to the
promise of eternal life with God in heaven
(CCC, no. 1521).

CA96F1BDB3D9412484F757D5533262E9.description:
Followers of Jesus Christ know that suffering
is never in vain because it can help one
move toward Heaven and eternal life. In our
suffering, we can help make up to some degree
for the hurt and harm we cause by our sin.

9005C391D0D749C19127C6B3D87A6E1E.description:
Jesus Christ also predicted that people would
suffer for their faith and promised that
he would be with them in their suffering.
Knowing this, believers try to accept suffering
patiently, to trust in God, and to pray for his
grace to sustain them. They rely on the Holy
Spirit’s gift of fortitude to grow in the virtue of
fortitude (CCC, nos. 1808, 1831).

71C59FD271AC4BC0A833F18375FD2DFE.description:
They are following the example of Jesus Christ,
who through his suffering and Death gained
salvation for us (CCC, no. 1505).

6666A3F58ACB4A618BD2947D43360D74.description:
Christians are willing to make sacrifices and
undergo suffering patiently for a number of reasons.

F49B2974D4674342A7D8D5F2C72E9D66.description:
Why are followers of Jesus Christ sometimes so willing
to make sacrifices and to accept pain and suffering,
especially in witness to Christ and their faith?

D29BFE68D4EC47869B876DBA9C2A1455.description:
In part, the Father allowed Jesus to suffer and die
the way he did in order to show us the gravity and
seriousness of sin.

A35285F2770E48549AEC38C64CD25884.description:
God the Father allowed his Son, Jesus, to suffer and
die because Jesus’ sacrifice destroyed the power of
sin and restored us to friendship with God.

FDD2C922699C46E4B21F0F27429C4AD8.description:
Because of Adam and Eve’s sin, all human beings
are born with a wounded human nature due to
the absence of the life of Christ’s grace, and so we
could not live eternally with God unless we were
redeemed (CCC, nos. 402-406).

AE1B78D440B840A2AA88EEEB9E5C5A5B.description:
God the Father allowed Jesus Christ, his Son, to
suffer and die the way he did because of his love for
all human beings; in that love, he wants us to live
eternally with him in heaven. His Passion reveals
the depth of the Father’s love in helping all people
to not be overcome by the magnitude of evil, sin,
and death.

4F87A8057F4E46E8BD733F3FDB48AE63.description:
Why would God the Father allow his Son, Jesus, to
suffer and die the way he did (CCC, nos. 599-609)?

501642E458BE492A82D9B87367DE7B58.description:
The Lord’s Prayer forms a basis for the Church’s
understanding of the value of prayer (CCC, nos.
2759-2865).

E51CBA170666418B839913A10C98DBDF.description:
Prayer requires effort and commitment (CCC, nos.
2729-2745).

CBAFF4B25BF94C96ACE3428D1FD5665B.description:
The forms of prayer are blessing, adoration, petition,
intercession, thanksgiving, and praise (CCC, nos.
2626-2649).

ACF7D8A60C514864AAA258F72E784CA0.description:
Expressions of prayer can be vocal, meditative, or
contemplative (CCC, nos. 2700-2724).

2BC48071C8734C859E9FEDFC80C61737.description:
Lectio divina is a way of praying on the Word of
God.

BF6F0F57AEA0496B9397FC256360561B.description:
Scripture is a guide, in that it gives us models
of praying in biblical figures and teaches us
about prayer.

3C8ECB9BD1AC4DBE892FACF4899BDE08.description:
Scripture is a source, in that many prayers come
out of the Bible or are partly based on Scriptural
passages or events: Mass prayers and dialogues,
psalms and canticles, Our Father, Hail Mary,
Angelus (CCC, nos. 2673-2679).

BB6CB465DC90409C9117BC26BB4B90B8.description:
Scripture is a source and guide for prayer (CCC, nos.
2567-2589, 2653-2654).

E6701FE9E7BE40E1BC18643247865D83.description:
Developing intimacy and communion with Jesus Christ
through prayer is an essential aspect in the life of a
believer or disciple (CT, no. 5; GDC, no. 80; NDC,
§19B; CCC, no. 2560).

694CD36A44DA4E77B52A113F65C27401.description:
God calls every individual to a vital relationship with
him experienced in prayer (CCC, no. 2558).

F18F8705D2F947C68B19FB8767461BCD.description: Prayer in the Life of a Believer

BA57A5CAB82A4382887B4259E3E9D221.description:
Fulfilling responsibility for the mission of
evangelization.

5CD1927C86D74BB0BD229BA649E9A00B.description:
Putting Jesus’ moral and spiritual teaching into
practice.

AC1B3CB207904287BCF35A258B79A4C0.description:
Living a sacramental life and a life of prayer (CCC,
nos. 562, 915, 1816, 1823, 1986, 2262, 2347, 2427,
2466, 2612).

5EB8362ADC0F4A6586A8D4CB6935C14F.description:
Worshiping and loving God as Jesus taught (CCC,
nos. 618, 767).

6663609CA97149BBB62DDE2B085BF6FA.description:
Conversion of heart and life, and the formation of
conscience (CCC, no. 1248).

7470AEFF919D46509D54F5A76725F0BC.description:
Adherence to Jesus and acceptance of his teaching
(CCC, nos. 520, 618, 767, 1693).

0E5857EE74164780ADA1C8D28CC08CE4.description: Living as a disciple of Jesus.

3EC5E37A4F884096864F923C7B7B7EF9.description:
We grow in holiness of life in and through the
Church (CCC, no. 2045).

CBA2380DD7804561AED8C58DA691475C.description:
Essential elements of a life growing in holiness:
interiority or reflection, self-examination, and
introspection (CCC, no. 1779).

317FD8F58AA24E20A59A994585CB719A.description:
Holy Spirit and grace enable us to live holiness of
life (CCC, no. 1704).

7962AFE5881549229158C0AC3BA91372.description:
Personal response to God’s call is shown in our way
of life (CCC, no. 2002).

7DE604DA832C49A1A9D0D46C0FC86DE1.description:
We are made in the image of God: intellect and
free will (CCC, nos. 1703-1706).

3F097D8A76E7463A85127ACD06BE7C9B.description:
Universal call to holiness of life (CCC, nos. 826,
2012-2014, 2028, 2045, 2813).

20304556E83F49DE95ED510AB0E56AD8.description:
The resurrection of the body and the Last
Judgment (CCC, nos. 988-1004).

BC093E096EEB48188B6C7C27041813D7.description:
Death and our judgment by God (CCC, nos.
678-679, 1006-1014).

E5903B44419E4E7A92A2CD30C68BE0BC.description:
By praying for the coming of the Kingdom of
God and by working toward that goal.

A04353144AFC4665ACC9A61BF3492F72.description:
By practicing the virtues of faith, hope, and
love (CCC, nos. 1812-1832).

831882C1C3F0417CA5EA8536FF5DAFEE.description:
We need to accept and live the grace of redemption
(CCC, no. 1803).

C18DEDA60D434C979126646D1B22FD75.description:
Eternal life with God in heaven is God’s desire for
us (CCC, nos. 1691-1698).

89DFDC2FA1A14046B3634F6B363F24E8.description:
Christ was put to death for our sins and was raised for
our justification (Rom 4:25; CCC, no. 598).

58D6E38E373A4FFE9FEC16953561E293.description: Moral Implications for the Life of a Believer

554DA8F4ADA848C7AB60ACA702C76D0D.description:
Where Jesus has gone, we hope to follow; Mary,
through her Assumption into heaven body and
soul, is an anticipation of the resurrection of others
who will follow (CCC, nos. 963-970).

44C12082DBC74E64A2731F3A99BE2009.description:
Jesus’ promise to be with us forever (Mt 28:20); the
sending of the Holy Spirit as part of the promise.

7D303CA56B9E427F9B19D9E0D3C57076.description:
The Ascension marks the entrance of Jesus’
humanity into heaven (CCC, no. 659).

E071E1A051424FA9A1ECF264E5EAE63C.description:
The Ascension and glorification of Jesus culminating in
the sending of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost (CCC, nos.
659-667).

2C4EF445B5FA4D98ACC0C811A72515E4.description:
We participate in the mystery of redemption
through the sacramental life of the Church,
especially the Holy Eucharist.

240B691533A743D2B6281549D6856DCD.description: A promise of our own resurrection (1 Cor 15).

07639D2C6CCB49DAB1F6521EF2EB2A88.description:
Fulfillment of the promises in the Old
Testament and of Jesus’ earthly promises
(CCC, no. 652).

677B34A4667E4DCEA690CC3EC822746D.description:
Confirmation of Jesus’ divinity and of his words
and teachings (CCC, nos. 651, 653).

5C33700EBC144DE793B48674AFD7FDA9.description:
The Resurrection is not a resuscitation or a
return to earthly life.

65BAF2635C3B401EA3C950A02E0CE825.description:
A transcendent event in which Jesus is no longer
bound by space and time.

1A034DFBDB3A4528B1BB6A4D52542760.description: Testified to by those who saw the Risen Jesus.

E4BDEFDBBD8D4E91BD0EF96DD0DD1341.description: A historical event involving Christ’s physical body.

78DAFD5BDE1C4E93A0270E70E7A7B5DC.description:
The Resurrection of Jesus: redemption accomplished
and the promise fulfilled (CCC, nos. 631-658).

256C2F2C0B3D4CEF89EDAF48CBABADAB.description:
Events of the Passion . . . the Suffering
Servant.

AB92BB96E657478BB8B72F96E39687A7.description:
The mystery of redemptive love and suffering on
the cross.

9D9DEC906B5942B8A7E54A64AC52D8D4.description: The Passion and Death of Jesus (CCC, nos. 595-618).

48D4CD332B7841A49BDEE440D4CD7EF2.description:
Jesus institutes the Sacrament of the Eucharist (CCC,
nos. 611, 1337-1344).

A420E9CD58C34363892C01DBD2C0B2E2.description:
The announcement of the Kingdom through parables
and miracles (CCC, nos. 541-550).

E7F2F0A20009414BA6137D3F76BE7DBD.description:
The miracle at the wedding feast of Cana (CCC,
no. 2618).

D54CB4E8D87A475796955AAA56227817.description:
The Baptism of Jesus and Jesus’ triple temptation
(CCC, nos. 538-540).

C6471ECB9D164E9C9863097FAFCDCB20.description:
Christ’s whole earthly life—words, deeds, silences,
sufferings—is a Revelation of the Father. Even the least characteristics of the mysteries of Jesus’ life
manifest God’s love among us (CCC, no. 516).

0155894E4F6044C09C123A72DA5887BF.description:
In his Cross and Resurrection he justified us
(CCC, no. 517).

3B2A2B5ECE484C94B1F91DD478207F45.description:
In his compassion and in his healings and
exorcisms he bore our infirmities.

47A8CBAD75B340B2A84FE4F7CA28092E.description:
In his preached word he purified our
consciences.

9D07647F566B418C905183D69271A42C.description:
In his hidden life his obedience atoned for
our disobedience.

AAB4A0A7101A4242A7C6C025EE5689A5.description:
By becoming poor he enriched us with
his poverty.

B70F8065CDDD4A73998D04818EA523EA.description:
Christ’s whole life was a mystery of redemption
(CCC, nos. 535-618).

04BD1ACB3A8A4B169E9CDDB1074DAA98.description: To destroy the power of the Devil (1 Jn 3:8).

CB2F0474869245D8ABD3244F8C9BFD7A.description:
To make us partakers of the divine nature
(CCC, nos. 457-460).

6DDB77887E81441A9753D39592B73559.description: To be our model of holiness (CCC, no. 459).

17376DB912CC44F08BD3CA628B0E9B85.description:
That we might come to know the depth of
God’s love for us (CCC, no. 458).

B7593A8B05BF48419371AD928F34012E.description:
To save us by reconciling us with God, who
loved us and sent his Son to be the expiation
for our sins (CCC, no. 457).

052305084F5940FBBBF37A57D446083B.description:
Why the Word became flesh (the Incarnation)
(CCC, nos. 525-528, 456-478).

3FAEA38D35734C7E8372A80E617215E0.description:
The Gospels apply the ancient prophesies to
Jesus (CCC, nos. 522-524).

B1F137A3FB724C9498DC5793F7512718.description:
The dream of St. Joseph; the role of St. Joseph
in the life of Jesus and Mary (CCC, nos.
496-507).

6BC8F702D757422F8C1801B2DA200BC2.description:
The Annunciation: Mary’s “yes” to God, her
consent to be the Mother of God (Theotokos)
(Lk 1:38; CCC, nos. 484-489).

7C34B126955E4BC5BCABAF2518AD5EF7.description:
The Gospels recognize Jesus as the fulfillment of
the promise.

8030B23C6835431ABB1CCA92CB528B90.description:
The promise of redemption is fulfilled in Jesus
(CCC, nos. 422-451).

11E3B8501A1A4EC69DDE6E1C01E72C38.description:
Judges, kings, and prophets: reminding the people
of ancient Israel about the promise.

5D0F924B59F84066A29628164D526B92.description:
The people of ancient Israel entrusted with
knowledge of God’s promise.

CE6555EB9A6644D1B40858C45B87CAF9.description:
Each of these covenants foreshadows the
Paschal Mystery (CCC, no. 129).

160C6231F233474AA38794448FF7F018.description:
God made a covenant with Noah, with
Abraham, and with Moses (CCC, nos. 56-64).

928265E789694B1AABD31C53294A9D3D.description:
The covenants are solemn commitments
between God and human beings (CCC, no.
56).

0D3AB5997821490C82B595E22FAE8C6C.description:
God’s covenants with Old Testament peoples
(CCC, nos. 129-130).

6BBECE814ED649E6AB2EC2B19217D003.description:
Longing for the fulfillment of the promise (CCC, nos.
121-123).

5857AE72CD7D45189DC56CB694EB135F.description:
Promise endures despite the escalation of sin (the
Book of Genesis: the murder of Abel, the Tower of
Babel, the Flood) (CCC, nos. 55-64).

E496055901194377A7BA4D8E446B4134.description:
God’s immediate response to Adam and Eve’s sin is
to promise redemption; this is the Proto-Evangelium,
the first announcement of the Good News (CCC,
nos. 410-412).

94AC700DF8A544DEA7F9BC84F5C80571.description:
The first prophecy of the Messiah, God’s promise to
redeem the world (Gn 3:15; CCC, no. 410).

139FF7ADFDD4420290F75CC4D243894F.description:
Original Sin and its consequences for all:
suffering, death, a tendency toward sin, need
for salvation (CCC, nos. 402-409).

93BF0352DF834CBCBCF9C4408C63D38B.description:
The consequences of Adam and Eve’s sin: loss
of paradise, original grace, original holiness,
and original justice (CCC, nos. 399-401).

6851D26DF4A54501BDB2412CEB011D4A.description:
The rebellion of Adam and Eve was a sin of
disobedience toward God, a rejection of a
God-centered life and the choice of a selfcentered life (CCC, nos. 396-398).

79AD99257ABE4F6B965038CDDF403297.description:
The rebellion of Adam and Eve and its
consequences.

B85B2ECE7C644A09BC80E2D79A22D910.description: The fall of the angels (CCC, nos. 391-395).

1180B5779C7946ADA17534B327002293.description:
The full meaning of the doctrine of Original Sin
is revealed only in the light of the Death and
Resurrection of Jesus. It is essential to belief in
the mystery of Christ. The whole of human
history is marked by the sin of the first parents
(CCC, no. 1708).

F7548ADEF2814D59898704FD2750B357.description:
The fall from grace: Original Sin (Gn 3; Rom 5:12;
CCC, nos. 55, 309-314, 385-390, 1707).

2032951C0DB4463D9E0137E175114AAD.description:
God’s plan: original holiness and original justice
(CCC, nos. 374-379).

D722FD4B73104501B6A3E866D352C1B4.description:
Human persons are a body-soul unity; this
reflects the physical and spiritual realities in
the world (CCC, nos. 356-368).

8FD8856C6B9544A9873C0D7D8D42B09E.description:
Contributions to the world and to the
Church (CCC, nos. 2346-2347).

C47505BBF2324132B0FC4EB6BBA00498.description:
Dignity of both men and women:
similarities and differences (CCC, nos.
2333-2336).

A6C5A4FF82EF4B37A81ED127C7458B22.description:
God made them male and female (CCC,
nos. 369-373, 1605, 1702, 2331).

0FD3E32898C541DDB31C3E52CC5609C5.description:
Created in the image and likeness of God
(CCC, nos. 356-359, 1700-1706).

17400B71A5E0443BA69C97C1A48842F9.description: Human beings as the summit of creation.

45EE23A9A56448A4BD2238FD6B33A582.description:
Unseen or invisible world: angels (CCC, nos.
325-336).

D2D256616F1243C49F67E740B0EC7815.description: God created all that is, seen and unseen.

75B9890ED86045A2AC744D6A4CBB057C.description:
The Trinitarian God is the Creator of all; all
creation reflects the glory of God (CCC, nos. 290-
295, 301).

DA4C548C7A2446A9AC06491F92463DBF.description:
Scripture’s use of figurative and symbolic
language in Genesis 1–11 (CCC, nos. 362,
375, 390, 396).

F5BBC7FF2C5F431898A5A49466103699.description:
The book reveals truth about which science
and history can only speculate.

C67C3B2EFC56481294FBF094EE356156.description:
Genesis 1–11 conveys religious truth rather
than science (CCC, nos. 283-289).

5E3DC8A7748A449681A45AFA1D730BDF.description:
Understanding literary forms in Scripture
(CCC, no. 289).

0B8C22B33CAE45E2BC3D9F4676DFF533.description: Revelation as found in the book of Genesis.

0D79C136788B4F8EBD73096487186CCF.description:
The Creation of the World and our first parents (CCC,
nos. 54, 279-282).

8148112493994FC4A6B40465DEBE575A.description:
The Goodness of Creation and
Our Fall from Grace
